content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-020-16-A |Item_parent=Health research methodology |Item_parent_short=Health research methodology |Rank=A |Title=Risk factor, aetiological factor, prognostic factor, health determinants, exposure factor |Description=Knowing how to define/recognise |Rubric=Definition |Contributors=Julie Berbis (CUESP),Alexandra Rouquette (CIMES),David Hajage (CIMES) |Order=16}} '''Exposure factor''': this is the factor of interest in an analytical or experimental study. * In an experimental study: it is the intervention (the drug, medical device, preventive intervention, etc.) to which study participants are exposed (or not) in an experimental manner. * In an analytical study, it is called a '''risk factor''', i.e. a factor associated with a higher probability (statistical and non-causal definition) of the presence or occurrence of the health phenomenon under study (judgment criterion). Example: yellow fingernails and lung cancer. ** In an etiological study, a risk factor is called an '''etiological factor''' when its causal nature for the health phenomenon studied is implied/supposed/proven. Example: smoking and lung cancer. ** Similarly, in a prognostic study, a risk factor is called a ''prognostic factor'' when its causal nature for the health phenomenon studied is implied/assumed/proven. Example: metastatic lung cancer and mortality. '''Health determinants''': factors which influence the state of health of populations, without necessarily being direct causes of particular problems or illnesses.

question.title: What is the term used to describe the factor of interest in an analytical or experimental study?
question.description: What is the term used to describe the factor of interest in an analytical or experimental study?

option_a.title: Exposure factor
option_a.description: The term used to describe the factor of interest in an analytical or experimental study

option_b.title: Health determinant
option_b.description: Factors that influence the state of health of populations

option_c.title: Risk factor
option_c.description: A factor associated with a higher probability of the presence or occurrence of a health phenomenon

option_d.title: Etiological factor
option_d.description: A factor that implies a causal nature for the health phenomenon studied

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The first letter of the correct option
